/COMMIT_MSG.message: Drop punctuation from the commit message title.

Not a blocker for me, just in case you want to improve it.
 
Tiny fraction of best practiced for commit messages:

1. use imperative for the title and don't use punctuation
   Add foo to bar when boo
   Not Adds or adding or Added or Added

2. Explain the 'why' of this patch and briefly the 'what'. Why is this patch needed? And what this patch does.
   This is not the full wording:
   Configure port 9100 for metrics collection for traefik in prometheus format. Metrics will be available and a prometheus instance can collect them.


https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages
This is much sorter and I prefer it in general:
https://github.com/erlang/otp/wiki/Writing-good-commit-messages

It is from the erlang language and has more links.

centos_tarball-dl.lst.message: Why are you downloading this as a tarball instead of using the src rpm?

Hi Jim:
   we can do this way , but what the major difference between using srpm and taking tarball in stx ?

srpm bundles the spec file with the source and other supporting files into one "official" delivery increment.  Copying a whackload of files out of a repo, instead of using a clone of the repo itself (eg. libvirt, qemu), just amounts to a Frankensteinian mess.  The fewer individual files we have store in our own repos, the better, especially if we don't have to modify any of them.

You don't have to wait for an srpm to be released, simply make it yourself:
1.  Clone the centos-git-common tools repo and add it to your $PATH
2.  cd to the kernel-rt repo and checkout the version you want
3.  run get_sources.sh
4.  run into_srpm.sh

Upload it to an appropriate stx managed repo on github or elsewhere.
Hi Jim, CentOS mirror doesn't have rt kernel srpm, this is why we have to use tarball. CentOS 7 rt kernel srpm is provided by CERN, and they have not released CentOS 8 rt kernel yet.
as discussed w/ Brent, there is no rt kernel srpm provided from centos8 , only tarball and Spec files https://git.centos.org/rpms/kernel-rt/tree/afa769a32d1a6db47a5cb57f48da7073f9a00925

One potential issue with this is that we run pre-run, run, and post-run playbooks as separate ansible invocations. That means this fact will only be available in the playbooks that run this role.

One way to deal with that is we could use ansible's include_role tasks_from argument to load just the bits that set the fact: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/modules/include_role_module.html#parameter-tasks_from

For that to work we would need to split this off into a separate tasks file and include it here. But then pre-run could ensure-pip as per normal then the run playbook can do something like:

  include_role:
    name: ensure-pip
    tasks_from: virtualenv_fact

We can just add:

  cacheable: true

and then this should work as is.

cyborg/agent/manager.py.message:
this is not correct this should still be CONF.host
see my comment on https://review.opendev.org/#/c/696014/2/cyborg/conf/default.py@37

Sean, that sounds correct. However, this is the host name that gets propagated to the Cyborg conductor which uses it to locate the compute node RP on which to hang the nested RP. That name should be the hypervisor hostname, which is obtained via gethostname() -- agreed? If so, see next comment.

The resource tracker is the component that actually sends the device report to the conductor, with the host name used to locate the CN RP [1]. It should be initialized here with host = gethostname(), I think.

As a bonus, it will fix the bug that the 'host' passed to ResourceTracker() here can be None, while the ResourceTracker never checks for that.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/cyborg/src/branch/master/cyborg/agent/resource_tracker.py#L75

resolutions/20200311-dissolving-ptl-role.message: Put another way, I think the real point of this change is to let projects die when there's no longer anybody who wants to do these things.

This resolution does not address who will assume responsibility for these things when there is no PTL to do so. This *is* the PTL's job, no matter how much you want to try to say it's "just a point of contact" or a "tiebreaker". If the PTL is abolished, no one will pick up this work and projects will die.

While this is true in some cases, it is not true in all of the project teams. We also already have a system of liaisons (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/CrossProjectLiaisons), "Lieutenants" (https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/pike/contributor/policies/neutron-teams.html#core-review-hierarchy), etc.
These items can be delegated by the PTL as many teams, such as Octavia, have.

all of these are things which PTLs are not mandated to do, and we're burning out people by having that huge workload on them.

the release liaison will make sure the release still happens, *any* contributor can unblock the gate, *any* contributor can organize PTG, *any* contributor can do project updates and on-boarding.  this doesn't have to be the ptl.

the hope is that teams can self-organize because most cores work together tightly enough to discuss and split these responsibilities between them

if they can't find a way to do that, I'm afraid that's a dysfunctional team unfortunately

There is difference between "doing the tasks" or "making sure that the task is done by somebody". I feel that when we say "anybody can organize PTG" is the "doing the task" part. But who will make sure that the person exists and knows that he has to do the organization? Is it the TC?
I don't think this can be a blanket statement. Some teams have flat or even growing involvement and a relatively high velocity(accounting for team size).

I disagree with this statement. I think we are confusing "need" with "are able". Personally I don't think the need has decreased. There are constant outside impacts to teams (cross project collaboration, community goals, dependency breakage, etc.) that having an individual take point is beneficial to the community.
Maybe not as formal or "public" as in the past. lol

I disagree. I think there is value in a point of contact and coordination. This includes teams that have already put "Lieutenants" structures in place.
Teams without a leader/point person tend to devolve with the following issues:
Someone will assume that role, but not get the recognition they deserve for the efforts, leading to burn out.
The team members will fall into "someone else will take care of that" mode.

In the second paragraph here the transition is made from "teams can choose to govern themselves differently" to "we're assuming all teams will choose to govern themselves using this new model".  I think that it would be better to lay the proposal out this way:

1. We want to let projects self-organize if they with because $REASONS

2. If a project wants to organize a different way then they should propose their self-governance plan to the governance repo and a "ptl-less" flag will be added to the project.  The TC will review and approve based on meeting the minimum team contact info criteria only.

3. Any teams that don't do this will continue to elect PTLs as has traditionally been done.
This already occurs under the current PTL structures, so I don't understand how this is a change really.
yes, the "liaisons" is still something that's being figured out and ideally we should minimize them as much as we can.

 >

 > traditionally been done.

I don't think we should have ptl and ptl-less, because pressure will be on project that are ptl-less to have a ptl, because they're going to "seem" less adequate or "less" performing.  it's a perception thing, we're humans.

TC would also condition approval based on compliance with the Four Opens and the other principles of OpenStack.  Since a team is self-organizing they could choose representation based on elections, a lottery system, a rotation schedule, or all cores who work for $VENDOR.  The TC would reject that last one as not in keeping with the diversity principle of OpenStack.

This is another red flag for me.
With the current election system, there is a healthy opportunity for a change in direction for teams.
Stagnant leadership for projects creates silos and limits the ability for new community members to grow their role.

This is a concern. This is one of the primary roles of a PTL. The person responsible for approving changes to sensitive roles, structure, etc.
When I was PTL in the past there were multiple occurrences where people outside the project team attempted to "propose" changes to the project structure, etc. that was caught by someone checking with the PTL before approving.

This doesn't make much sense to me.  From arch/x86/include/asm/spec_ctrl.h:

/*
 * The BIT() macro is a shift by 1UL, and it is used as part of the
 * SPEC_CTRL_IBRS macro.  Older assemblers (prior to binutils 2.28) do
 * not accept the L or LL suffixes, however.  Redefine BIT here in a
 * way that will work with the older toolchains.
 */
#undef BIT
#define BIT(nr) (_AC(1,UL) << (nr))

This *should* work imo.

This definition is not used in msr-index.h
1. msr-index.h is included before this defintion in spec_ctrl.h
2. msr-index.h will include "<linux/bits.h>", then lead to this error.

I will port BIT definition in spec_ctrl.h to msr-index.h to fix the issue.

I can't find where tempestconf execution in the featureset39 gate is, but this will likely fail - default('omit') will store 'omit' within overrides var, which is not expected and python-tempestconf will complain. Even if it was default(omit) it would fail because that puts an ansible omit object to the variable and again, that's not expected and tempestconf will complain. Based on few experiments I did in my ansible sandbox, default(None) should work -> it will put an empty string to the variable and python-tempestconf will translate it as an empty list - behavior when no overrides are present, which is the situation here.

NOTE: also default('') would work

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/716060/

The content of tempest_tempestconf_profile is using to_nice_yaml dumped to a profile.yaml file which is passed later to python-tempestconf.
https://github.com/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_tempest/blob/f5e2828e52413b3639c3ca4796aa377bef581f26/tasks/tempestconf.yml#L28

Technically one of the following is acceptable here:
- overrides is not set at all -> python-tempestconf uses its default set internaly
- default(None) - which results in empty string, which is accepted
- default('')
- default('{}')
- default({}) - will result in the same value as the above
- default('[]')
- default([]) - will result in the same value as the above

In the patch I linked above I decided for default({}) to keep consistency as that's also shown in the tempestconf's doc: https://docs.openstack.org/python-tempestconf/latest/user/profile.html

by the way we have that in a LOT of places... I copied the above from one of the other featuresets but if you go to the config/general_config directory you can see:

I don't think this is on the right track, and doubt the size of the amphora image file we're trying to upload to glance is actually 0. The file is streamed to glance via HTTP, and the message you see from glance's rbd driver is simply the driver indicating it doesn't know the amount of data coming its way, and so it needs to keep allocating chunks for the rbd volume volume it's writing.

I'm told by rosmaita that the image upload command is synchronous, and it may just be taking longer than the 600 sec urllib timeout.

ansible/inventory/all-in-one.message: If the default is routing on computes, should we deploy ovn-controller on network hosts?

It's in the reference architecture from networking-ovn - https://docs.openstack.org/networking-ovn/latest/admin/refarch/refarch.html#service-layout - so I think we should keep it there. 
And if the reference arch defines using gateway nodes and no distributed FIP - I'll update the change so it's the default.
That document describes both approaches - centralised FIPs & DVR.
Looks like it's controlled by [ovn] enable_distributed_floating_ip in neutron-server ml2_conf.ini, default is false.

Looking at the refarch (https://docs.openstack.org/networking-ovn/latest/admin/refarch/refarch.html), it defines these types of nodes:

* Controller: openstack services
* Database: ovn-northd, ovn-nb-db, ovn-sb-db
* Compute: ovn-controller, ovs-vswitchd, ovsdb-server, ovn-metadata-agent
* Gateway: ovn-controller, ovs-vswitchd, ovsdb-server

And then: "For functional evaluation only, you can combine the controller and database nodes."

I'd say gateway == network node.

So I'm wondering if the database services (ovn-northd, ovn-nb-db, ovn-sb-db) should really live on the controller in this setup?

Also let's make a group for neutron-ovn-metadata-agent on the computes rather than reusing the compute group.
neutron-server is control. Only data path services are in the network group.
++ - we could possibly have another major group for "ovn-database" defaulting to controller for sake of simplicity (I guess for small scale it does not do any bad)
Well, we default Neutron server to network group - so we should collocate it there, but still make a parent group "ovn-database" for easy modification.
a huge accident, fortunately only octavia was the victim...

ansible/roles/neutron/defaults/main.yml.message: could be just entrypoint name ovn-router rather than python path https://github.com/openstack/networking-ovn/blob/master/setup.cfg#L58 ?

here example what I mean by switching to using neutron_plugin_agent:
 neutron_plugin_agent in ['ovn']

This way you make it clear it depends on neutron plugin agent and hence the vxlan above is normally going to go away. Otherwise it is no longer clear.
Not really the case. Provider =/= tenant vlan.
I would drop these simply to retain compatibility (and sanity).
It's half the case, but we don't have a variable enable_tenant_vlan - still a user can override the whole var (or config file).
I see you are helping ironic guys, but it might be the case they are running on vlan instead. To think about it.
I took this from previous form of this variable and a comment: https://github.com/openstack/kolla-ansible/blob/6dde7ce833472c963610e43073d75b2c0f764fbd/ansible/group_vars/all.yml#L897
But it only has a comment about it. Ditto above.
or - do not enable when HyperV or OVN (not both)
oh just do it like for the one below :-)
What about bgp and sriov btw? Work/break? OVN/Neutron?
Uhm, they are agents... See the agent below. The question is whether OVN supports them natively, breaks totally or depends on Neutron.
First of all, bgp and sriov are never used in our code as values for neutron_plugin_agent - so I'm not breaking anything that is not broken already ;-)
Right, in case of BGP we need to disable it when OVN is enabled, because it won't work at all (bgp neutron agent requires l3 agent to work). OVN needs SR-IOV NIC agent to deliver SR-IOV.
We normally use this data for looping over containers - if only one has an attribute it's probably better as a top level variable (neutron_metadata_agent_config_file)
I think this should be a separate service. It's a different binary, runs on different hosts, and should have a different name.
Sorry, forgot - well, Radoslaw pointed out it should be the same - I can add a new entry - no problem - just work out a common decision :-)
Since this is a different binary with different behavior - maybe we should still use a separate image? That would avoid the last bastion of confusion. ;-)

and, now you have l2population enabled! https://9e3c7783c34af633d765-877a0f70cfb612990952d1399a198d7a.ssl.cf2.rackcdn.com/696841/134/check/kolla-ansible-centos8-source-ovn/2ec19a9/primary/logs/kolla_configs/neutron-server/ml2_conf.ini
